member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.apps.jportmap.jportmap.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new portmap instance, create the transport registration information and UDP and TCP-based transports, which will be bound later to port 111.
member.remarks: Create a new portmap instance, create the transport registration information and UDP and TCP-based transports, which will be bound later to port 111. The constructor does not start the dispatcher loop.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.apps.jportmap.jportmap.getPort(org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcServerIdent)
member.summary: Lookup port for (program, version, protocol).
member.remarks: Lookup port for (program, version, protocol). If no suitable registration entry if found and an entry with another version, but the same program and version number is found, this is returned instead. This is compatible with the way Sun's portmap implementation works.
member.param: server identification (program, version, protocol) to look up. The port field is not used.
member.returns: port number where server listens for incomming ONC/RPC calls, or 0, if no server is registered for (program, protocol).

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.apps.jportmap.jportmap.setPort(org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcServerIdent)
member.summary: Register a port number for a particular (program, version, protocol).
member.remarks: Register a port number for a particular (program, version, protocol). Note that a caller can not register the same (program, version, protocol) for another port. In this case we return false. Thus, a caller first needs to deregister any old entries which it whishes to update. Always add new registration entries to the end of the list (vector).
member.param: (program, version, protocol, port) to register.
member.returns: true if registration succeeded.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.apps.jportmap.jportmap.unsetPort(org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcServerIdent)
member.summary: Deregister all port settings for a particular (program, version) for all transports (TCP, UDP, ...).
member.remarks: Deregister all port settings for a particular (program, version) for all transports (TCP, UDP, ...). While these are strange semantics, they are compatible with Sun's portmap implementation.
member.param: (program, version) to deregister. The protocol and port fields are not used.
member.returns: true if deregistration succeeded.

member.summary: The class OncRpcEmbeddedPortmap provides an embeddable portmap service, which is automatically started in its own thread if the (operating) system does not already provide the portmap service.

Jay Walters

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_SUCCESS
member.summary: The remote procedure was called and executed successfully.
member.remarks: The remote procedure was called and executed successfully.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_UNAVAIL
member.summary: The program requested is not available.
member.remarks: The program requested is not available. So the remote host does not export this particular program and the ONC/RPC server which you tried to send a RPC call message doesn't know of this program either.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROG_MISMATCH
member.summary: A program version number mismatch occured.
member.remarks: A program version number mismatch occured. The remote ONC/RPC server does not support this particular version of the program.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_PROC_UNAVAIL
member.summary: The procedure requested is not available.
member.remarks: The procedure requested is not available. The remote ONC/RPC server does not support this particular procedure.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_GARBAGE_ARGS
member.summary: The server could not decode the arguments sent within the ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks: The server could not decode the arguments sent within the ONC/RPC call message.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcAcceptStatus.ONCRPC_SYSTEM_ERR
member.summary: The server encountered a system error and thus was not able to process the procedure call.
member.remarks: The server encountered a system error and thus was not able to process the procedure call. Causes might be memory shortage, desinterest and sloth.

member.summary: The so-called "Unix" authentication scheme is not supported.
member.remarks: The so-called "Unix" authentication scheme is not supported. This one only sends the users id as well as her/his group identifiers, so this is simply far too weak to use in typical situations where authentication is requested.

member.summary: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server. If the timeout expires, call(int, XdrAble, XdrAble) will raise a InterruptedIOException . The default timeout value is 30 seconds (30,000 milliseconds). The timeout must be > 0. A timeout of zero indicated batched calls, for which no reply message is expected.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.returns: Current timeout.

member.name: T:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcMessage class is an abstract superclass for all the message types ONC/RPC defines (well, an overwhelming count of two).
member.remarks: The OncRpcMessage class is an abstract superclass for all the message types ONC/RPC defines (well, an overwhelming count of two). The only things common to all ONC/RPC messages are a message identifier and the message type. All other things do not come in until derived classes are introduced. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessage.#ctor(System.Int32)

member.remarks: Constructs a new OncRpcMessage object with default values: a given message type and no particular message identifier.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessage.messageId
member.summary: The message id is used to identify matching ONC/RPC calls and replies.
member.remarks: The message id is used to identify matching ONC/RPC calls and replies. This is typically choosen by the communication partner sending a request. The matching reply then must have the same message identifier, so the receiver can match calls and replies.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessage.messageType
member.summary: The kind of ONC/RPC message, which can be either a call or a reply.
member.remarks: The kind of ONC/RPC message, which can be either a call or a reply. Can be one of the constants defined in OncRpcMessageType .

member.name: T:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessageType
member.summary: A collection of constants used for ONC/RPC messages to identify the type of message.
member.remarks: A collection of constants used for ONC/RPC messages to identify the type of message. Currently, ONC/RPC messages can be either calls or replies. Calls are sent by ONC/RPC clients to servers to call a remote procedure (for you "ohohpies" that can be translated into the buzzword "method"). A server then will answer with a corresponding reply message (but not in the case of batched calls). Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessageType.ONCRPC_CALL
member.summary: Identifies an ONC/RPC call.
member.remarks: Identifies an ONC/RPC call. By a "call" a client request that a server carries out a particular remote procedure.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcMessageType.ONCRPC_REPLY
member.summary: Identifies an ONC/RPC reply.
member.remarks: Identifies an ONC/RPC reply. A server responds with a "reply" after a client has sent a "call" for a particular remote procedure, sending back the results of calling that procedure.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_UDP
member.summary: Use the UDP protocol of the IP (Internet Protocol) suite as the network communication protocol for doing remote procedure calls.
member.remarks: Use the UDP protocol of the IP (Internet Protocol) suite as the network communication protocol for doing remote procedure calls. This is the same as the IPPROTO_UDP definition from the famous BSD socket API.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_TCP
member.summary: Use the TCP protocol of the IP (Internet Protocol) suite as the network communication protocol for doing remote procedure calls.
member.remarks: Use the TCP protocol of the IP (Internet Protocol) suite as the network communication protocol for doing remote procedure calls. This is the same as the IPPROTO_TCP definition from the famous BSD socket API.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcProtocols.ONCRPC_HTTP
member.summary: Use the HTTP application protocol for tunneling ONC remote procedure calls.
member.remarks: Use the HTTP application protocol for tunneling ONC remote procedure calls. This is definetely not similiar to any definition in the famous BSD socket API.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcTcpClient.batchCall(System.Int32,org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Issues a batched call for a remote procedure to an ONC/RPC server.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcTcpClient.setTimeout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server.
member.remarks:
Set the timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server. If the timeout expires, OncRpcClient.call(int, XdrAble, XdrAble)
will raise a InterruptedIOException . The default timeout value is 30 seconds (30,000 milliseconds). The timeout must be > 0. A timeout of zero indicates a batched call, for which no reply message is expected.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcTcpClient.setTransmissionTimeout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the timeout used during transmission of data.
member.remarks: Set the timeout used during transmission of data. If the flow of data when sending calls or receiving replies blocks longer than the given timeout, an exception is thrown. The timeout must be > 0.
member.param: Transmission timeout in milliseconds.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpClient.setRetransmissionTimeout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the retransmission timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server before resending the call.
member.remarks: Set the retransmission timout for remote procedure calls to wait for an answer from the ONC/RPC server before resending the call. The default retransmission timeout is the 30 seconds. The retransmission timeout must be > 0. To disable retransmission of lost calls, set the retransmission timeout to be the same value as the timeout.
member.param: Timeout in milliseconds. A timeout of zero indicates batched calls.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpClient.retransmissionTimeout
member.summary: Retransmission timeout used for resending ONC/RPC calls when an ONC/RPC server does not answer fast enough.
member.remarks: Retransmission timeout used for resending ONC/RPC calls when an ONC/RPC server does not answer fast enough. The default retransmission timeout is identical to the overall timeout for ONC/RPC calls (thus UDP/IP-based clients will not retransmit lost calls).

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpClient.retransmissionMode
member.summary: Retransmission mode used when resending ONC/RPC calls.
member.remarks: Retransmission mode used when resending ONC/RPC calls. Default mode is fixed timeout mode .

member.name: T:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpRetransmissionMode
member.summary: A collection of constants used to identify the retransmission schemes when using UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients . Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpRetransmissionMode.EXPONENTIAL
member.summary: In exponentional back-off retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients first wait a given retransmission timeout period before sending the ONC/RPC call again.
member.remarks: In exponentional back-off retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients first wait a given retransmission timeout period before sending the ONC/RPC call again. The retransmission timeout then is doubled on each try.

member.name: F:org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcUdpRetransmissionMode.FIXED
member.summary: In fixed retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients wait a given retransmission timeout period before send the ONC/RPC call again.
member.remarks: In fixed retransmission mode, UDP/IP-based ONC/RPC clients wait a given retransmission timeout period before send the ONC/RPC call again. The retransmission timeout is not changed between consecutive tries but is fixed instead.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.#ctor(org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerTransport)
member.summary: Create an OncRpcCallInformation object and associate it with a ONC/RPC server transport.
member.remarks: Create an OncRpcCallInformation object and associate it with a ONC/RPC server transport. Typically, OncRpcCallInformation objects are created by transports once before handling incoming calls using the same call info object. To support multithreaded handling of calls in the future (for UDP/IP), the transport is already divided from the call info.
member.param: ONC/RPC server transport.

member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved.

if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.summary: Finishes call parameter deserialization.

member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.beginEncoding(org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage)
member.summary: Begins the sending phase for ONC/RPC replies.
member.remarks:
Begins the sending phase for ONC/RPC replies. After beginning sending you can serialize the reply/result (but only if the call was accepted, see org.acplt.oncrpc.OncRpcReplyMessage
for details). The stream to use for serialization can be obtained using getXdrEncodingStream() . This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.param: ONC/RPC reply header indicating success or failure.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.beginEncoding
member.summary: Begins the sending phase for accepted ONC/RPC replies.
member.remarks: Begins the sending phase for accepted ONC/RPC replies. After beginning sending you can serialize the result/reply. The stream to use for serialization can be obtained using getXdrEncodingStream() . This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.getXdrEncodingStream
member.summary: Returns XDR stream which can be used for eserializing the reply to this ONC/RPC call.
member.remarks: Returns XDR stream which can be used for eserializing the reply to this ONC/RPC call. This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.returns: Reference to enecoding XDR stream.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.endEncoding
member.summary: Finishes encoding the reply to this ONC/RPC call.
member.remarks: Finishes encoding the reply to this ONC/RPC call. Afterwards you must not use the XDR stream returned by getXdrEncodingStream() any longer.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation.reply(org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage,org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the caller who sent in this call.
member.remarks: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the caller who sent in this call. This is a low-level function and typically should not be used by call dispatchers. Instead use the other reply method which just expects a serializable object to send back to the caller.
member.param: ONC/RPC reply message header indicating success or failure and containing associated state information.
If not null, then this parameter references the reply to be serialized after the reply message header.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.remarks: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the caller who sent in this call. This automatically sends an ONC/RPC reply header before the reply part, indicating success within the header.
member.param: Reply body the ONC/RPC reply message.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: T:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerCallMessage
member.summary: The OncRpcServerCallMessage class represents an ONC/RPC call message on the server side.
member.remarks: The OncRpcServerCallMessage class represents an ONC/RPC call message on the server side. For this reasons it just handles decoding of call messages but can not do any encoding. This class is also responsible for pulling off authentication information from the wire and converting it into appropriate authentication protocol handling objects. As with all good management, this class therefor delegates this somehow unpleasant work to the server-side authentication protocol handling classes. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.

Jay Walters

Notify the RPC server to stop processing of remote procedure call requests as soon as possible. Note that each transport has its own thread, so processing will not stop before the transports have been closed by calling the close(org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerTransport[])
method of the server.

member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks:
Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved. Under the hood this method therefore calls org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.endDecoding()
to free any pending resources from the decoding stage.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.remarks:
Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller. This is rather a low-level method, typically not used by applications. Dispatcher handling ONC/RPC calls have to use the OncRpcCallInformation.reply(org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble)
method instead on the call object supplied to the handler.

Using a server transport, ONC/RPC calls are received and the corresponding replies are sent back. member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.retrieveCall(org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message.
member.remarks:
Retrieves the parameters sent within an ONC/RPC call message. It also makes sure that the deserialization process is properly finished after the call parameters have been retrieved. Under the hood this method therefore calls org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.endDecoding()
to free any pending resources from the decoding stage.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.returns: Reference to decoding XDR stream.

member.summary: Finishes call parameter deserialization.
member.remarks: Finishes call parameter deserialization. Afterwards the XDR stream returned by getXdrDecodingStream() must not be used any more. This method belongs to the lower-level access pattern when handling ONC/RPC calls.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully deserialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcUdpServerTransport.reply(org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcCallInformation,org.acplt.oncrpc.server.OncRpcServerReplyMessage,org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble)
member.summary: Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller.
member.remarks:
Send back an ONC/RPC reply to the original caller. This is rather a low-level method, typically not used by applications. Dispatcher handling ONC/RPC calls have to use the OncRpcCallInformation.reply(org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrAble)
method instead on the call object supplied to the handler.
member.param: information about the original call, which are necessary to send back the reply to the appropriate caller.
ONC/RPC reply message header indicating success or failure and containing associated state information.
If not null, then this parameter references the reply to be serialized after the reply message header.
member.exception: if an ONC/RPC exception occurs, like the data could not be successfully serialized.
if an I/O exception occurs, like transmission failures over the network, etc.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream. This is different from xdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) where first the length of the opaque value is retrieved from the XDR stream.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferEncodingStream.endEncoding
member.summary: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out.
member.remarks: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out. The general contract of endEncoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is finished and any bytes previously encoded should immediately be written to their intended destination.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferEncodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. The general contract of close is that it closes the encoding XDR stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform encoding operations and cannot be reopened.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferEncodingStream.xdrEncodeInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrBufferEncodingStream.xdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the given length is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.beginDecoding
member.summary: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.
member.remarks: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record. This typically involves filling the internal buffer with the next datagram from the network, or reading the next chunk of data from a stream-oriented connection. In case of memory-based communication this might involve waiting for some other process to fill the buffer and signal availability of new XDR data.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.xdrDecodeInt
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on. Because it's so basic, derived classes have to implement it.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.xdrDecodeDynamicOpaque
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. The length of the opaque value to decode is pulled off of the XDR stream, so the caller does not need to know the exact length in advance. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.returns: The byte vector containing the decoded data.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrDecodingStream.xdrDecodeByteVector
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int). Byte vectors are decoded together with a preceeding length value. This way the receiver doesn't need to know the length of the vector in advance.
member.returns: The byte vector containing the decoded data.

member.remarks: Begins encoding a new XDR record. This typically involves resetting this encoding XDR stream back into a known state.
member.param: Indicates the receiver of the XDR data. This can be null for XDR streams connected permanently to a receiver (like in case of TCP/IP based XDR streams).
Port number of the receiver.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrEncodingStream.xdrEncodeInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on. Because it's so basic, derived classes have to implement it.
member.param: The int value to be encoded.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrEncodingStream.xdrEncodeDynamicOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. The length of the opaque value is written to the XDR stream, so the receiver does not need to know the exact length in advance. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four to maintain XDR alignment.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrEncodingStream.xdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the length of the given byte vector is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrEncodingStream.xdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32)

member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the length of the given byte vector is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.
member.param: The opaque value to be encoded in the form of a series of bytes.
of vector to write. This parameter is used as a sanity check.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrEncodingStream.xdrEncodeByteVector(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int).
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a vector of bytes, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes), each packed into its very own 4 bytes (XDR int). Byte vectors are encoded together with a preceeding length value. This way the receiver doesn't need to know the length of the vector in advance.
member.param: Byte vector to encode.

member.name: T:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream
member.summary: The XdrTcpDecodingStream class provides the necessary functionality to XdrDecodingStream to receive XDR records from the network using the stream-oriented TCP/IP. Converted to C# using the db4o Sharpen tool.
member.author: Harald Albrecht
Jay Walters

member.summary: Construct a new XdrTcpDecodingStream object and associate it with the given networkStream for TCP/IP-based communication.
member.remarks: Construct a new XdrTcpDecodingStream object and associate it with the given networkStream for TCP/IP-based communication.
member.param: Socket from which XDR data is received.
Size of packet buffer for storing received XDR data.

member.summary: Returns the Internet address of the sender of the current XDR data.
member.remarks: Returns the Internet address of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after beginDecoding() , otherwise it might return stale information.
member.returns: InetAddress of the sender of the current XDR data.

member.summary: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data.
member.remarks: Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after beginDecoding() , otherwise it might return stale information.
member.returns: Port number of the sender of the current XDR data.

buffer receiving data.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.xdrDecodeInt
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream. This is different from xdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) where first the length of the opaque value is retrieved from the XDR stream.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.

member.summary: The buffer which will be filled from the datagram socket and then be used to supply the information when decoding data.
member.remarks: The buffer which will be filled from the datagram socket and then be used to supply the information when decoding data.

Jay Walters

Returns the Internet address of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after beginEncoding(IPAddress, int)

Returns the port number of the sender of the current XDR data. This method should only be called after beginEncoding(IPAddress, int)

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.beginEncoding(System.Net.IPAddress,System.Int32)
member.summary: Begins encoding a new XDR record.
member.remarks: Begins encoding a new XDR record. This typically involves resetting this encoding XDR stream back into a known state.
member.param: Indicates the receiver of the XDR data. This can be null for XDR streams connected permanently to a receiver (like in case of TCP/IP based XDR streams).
Port number of the receiver.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.endEncoding
member.summary: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out.
member.remarks: Flushes this encoding XDR stream and forces any buffered output bytes to be written out. The general contract of endEncoding is that calling it is an indication that the current record is finished and any bytes previously encoded should immediately be written to their intended destination.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.endEncoding(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Ends the current record fort this encoding XDR stream.
member.remarks: Ends the current record fort this encoding XDR stream. If the parameter flush is true any buffered output bytes are immediately written to their intended destination. If flush is false, then more than one record can be pipelined, for instance, to batch several ONC/RPC calls. In this case the ONC/RPC server must not send a reply (with the exception for the last call in a batch, which might be trigger a reply). Otherwise, you will most probably cause an interaction deadlock between client and server.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.flush(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Flushes the current contents of the buffer as one fragment to the network.
member.remarks: Flushes the current contents of the buffer as one fragment to the network.
member.param: true if this is the last fragment of the current XDR record.
if last fragment and batch is true, then the buffer is not flushed to the network but instead we wait for more records to be encoded.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.Close
member.summary: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream.
member.remarks: Closes this encoding XDR stream and releases any system resources associated with this stream. The general contract of close is that it closes the encoding XDR stream. A closed XDR stream cannot perform encoding operations and cannot be reopened.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.xdrEncodeInt(System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a "XDR int" value and writes it down a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has. This method is one of the basic methods all other methods can rely on.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrTcpEncodingStream.xdrEncodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Encodes (aka "serializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is encoded, but no length indication is preceeding the opaque value, so the receiver has to know how long the opaque value will be. The encoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four. If the given length is not a multiple of four, zero bytes will be used for padding.

member.summary: Initiates decoding of the next XDR record.

member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a "XDR int" value received from a XDR stream. A XDR int is 32 bits wide -- the same width Java's "int" data type has.
member.returns: The decoded int value.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrUdpDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes).
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") an opaque value, which is nothing more than a series of octets (or 8 bits wide bytes). Because the length of the opaque value is given, we don't need to retrieve it from the XDR stream. This is different from xdrDecodeOpaque(byte[], int, int) where first the length of the opaque value is retrieved from the XDR stream.
member.param: Length of opaque data to decode.
member.returns: Opaque data as a byte vector.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrUdpDecodingStream.xdrDecodeOpaque(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length.
member.remarks: Decodes (aka "deserializes") a XDR opaque value, which is represented by a vector of byte values, and starts at offset with a length of length. Only the opaque value is decoded, so the caller has to know how long the opaque value will be. The decoded data is always padded to be a multiple of four (because that's what the sender does).
member.param: Byte vector which will receive the decoded opaque value.
Start offset in the byte vector.
the number of bytes to decode.

member.name: M:org.acplt.oncrpc.XdrUnion.getXdrTypeCode
member.summary: Returns the so-called type code which identifies a derived class when encoded or decoded.
member.remarks: Returns the so-called type code which identifies a derived class when encoded or decoded. Note that the type code is not globally unique, but rather it is only unique within the derived classes of a direct descend of XdrUnion. If foo is derived from XdrUnion and foo is the base class for bar and baz, then the type code needs only be unique between bar and baz.
member.returns: Type code identifying an object's class when encoding or decoding the object into or from a XDR stream.
